name: Tech Meeting Phrases
description: Common phrases and idioms used in online tech meetings. Listen to the audio and learn the sentence and its common alternatives.

sideB: Can everyone see my screen?
Is my screen share coming through?
Let me know if you can see my screen.
cards.note: This is often the very first question asked after joining a call to ensure the presentation is visible to all participants.

sideB: Sorry, I was on mute.
My apologies, I was muted.
Oops, you couldn't hear me, I was on mute.
cards.note: Arguably the most common phrase of the remote work era. A universal experience for online meeting attendees.

sideB: Let's circle back to this later.
Can we park this discussion for now?
Let's put a pin in that and revisit it.
cards.note: A polite and professional way to postpone a topic that is off-topic or requires more time, keeping the meeting focused.

sideB: I'll push the changes to the dev branch.
I'm committing the code to the development branch now.
The updates are being pushed to dev.
cards.note: In Git version control, 'pushing' sends your local code changes to a remote repository. The 'dev branch' is a common branch for active development.

sideB: We need to merge this PR by end of day.
This pull request needs to be merged before we leave.
Let's get this PR merged today.
cards.note: 'PR' stands for Pull Request, a formal request to merge code into a branch. 'End of day' (EOD) adds a sense of urgency.

sideB: What's the ETA for this feature?
Do we have an estimated time of arrival for this functionality?
When can we expect this feature to be delivered?
cards.note: 'ETA' stands for 'Estimated Time of Arrival'. It's a standard project management term to ask for a delivery forecast.

sideB: This is causing a blocker for the testing team.
The testers are blocked by this issue.
This is a blocking issue for QA.
cards.note: A 'blocker' is a high-priority issue that prevents a team (like QA or testing) from doing their work. It requires immediate attention.

sideB: Let's sync up offline about this.
Can we have a quick chat about this separately?
Let's take this conversation offline.
cards.note: Ironically, 'offline' in a remote work context usually means having a separate, smaller online call or direct message conversation.

sideB: The latest build failed in the CI/CD pipeline.
Our continuous integration pipeline broke on the last build.
The build is red in the pipeline.
cards.note: 'CI/CD' (Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment) is an automated system for building and testing code. A failed build means the latest changes broke something.

sideB: Can you grant me permissions to access the staging environment?
I need access rights for the staging server.
Could you provide me with staging access credentials?
cards.note: A 'staging environment' is a server that mirrors the live production environment. It's used for final testing before a public release.

sideB: I'm having some latency issues.
There's a significant lag on my end.
My connection seems to be slow.
cards.note: 'Latency' refers to the delay in data transfer. It's the technical term for what users often perceive as 'lag'.

sideB: We need to refactor this module.
This piece of code needs a major refactor.
It's time to restructure this module for better maintainability.
cards.note: 'Refactoring' means restructuring existing computer code—changing the factoring—without changing its external behavior. It improves nonfunctional attributes of the software.

sideB: Let's check the logs to see what went wrong.
The error details should be in the log files.
Can we review the logs for more information?
cards.note: 'Logs' are automatically generated files that record events and errors from an application. They are essential for debugging problems.

sideB: The API is returning a 500 error.
We're getting a server error from the API.
The API endpoint is failing with a 500 status code.
cards.note: A '500 Internal Server Error' is a generic HTTP status code indicating that something has gone wrong on the web server, but the server could not be more specific.

sideB: Does this align with the project's scope?
Is this feature within the scope of the current sprint?
We should confirm if this is part of the agreed-upon scope.
cards.note: This question is crucial for preventing 'scope creep'—the tendency for project requirements to expand beyond their original goals.

sideB: I'll create a ticket for this bug in Jira.
Let me log this issue in our tracking system.
A new bug report for this will be created.
cards.note: 'Jira' is a very popular issue-tracking product. A 'ticket' is a single work item in such a system.

sideB: We have a merge conflict that needs to be resolved.
There's a conflict in the code merge.
Someone needs to resolve the merge conflicts on this branch.
cards.note: A 'merge conflict' occurs in version control systems like Git when two developers have changed the same line of code in different branches.

sideB: The documentation for this endpoint is outdated.
We need to update the API documentation.
The current docs don't reflect the latest changes.
cards.note: Outdated documentation is a common source of confusion and bugs for developers using an API or a library.

sideB: Let's do a quick code review on this.
Can I get another pair of eyes on this code?
This is ready for a peer review.
cards.note: A 'code review' is a standard software quality assurance practice where developers check each other's code for mistakes and improvements.

sideB: This change will require a database migration.
We'll need to run a migration script for this schema change.
A database migration is necessary to support this update.
cards.note: A 'database migration' is a controlled set of changes to update the structure (schema) of a database, like adding a new table or a new column.

sideB: I'm dropping off, I have another meeting.
I have to jump to another call, catch you later.
I have a hard stop now, talk to you all soon.
cards.note: A 'hard stop' is a non-negotiable end time for a meeting, indicating you must leave at that exact time for another commitment.

sideB: What's the bandwidth of the team for next sprint?
How much capacity do we have for the upcoming sprint?
What's our team's availability look like for the next sprint?
cards.note: In a business context, 'bandwidth' is a metaphor for a person's or team's capacity to take on more work.

sideB: We need to rollback the last deployment.
Let's revert to the previous version.
The last release needs to be rolled back immediately.
cards.note: A 'rollback' is the process of reverting a software deployment to a previous, stable version. It's a critical emergency procedure.

sideB: This seems like a low-hanging fruit.
This is an easy win we can tackle quickly.
This task should be straightforward to implement.
cards.note: The idiom 'low-hanging fruit' refers to a task or goal that is easily achievable and can be tackled without much effort.

sideB: Could you please elaborate on that point?
Can you give us more details on that?
I'm not sure I follow, could you explain further?
cards.note: This is a polite and professional way to ask for more detailed information when you don't fully understand something.

sideB: Let's move on to the next agenda item.
Shall we proceed to the next topic?
Okay, let's go to the next point on our agenda.
cards.note: A phrase typically used by the meeting facilitator to keep the discussion on track and manage time effectively.

sideB: I'll take ownership of this task.
I can take the lead on this one.
Assign this task to me, I'll handle it.
cards.note: 'Taking ownership' is a key concept in agile methodologies, signifying responsibility and accountability for a task's completion.

sideB: We need to address the technical debt in this area.
This part of the codebase has a lot of tech debt.
Let's prioritize paying down some of this technical debt.
cards.note: 'Technical debt' is a metaphor for the implied cost of rework caused by choosing an easy (limited) solution now instead of using a better approach that would take longer.

sideB: This approach doesn't seem scalable.
I'm concerned about the scalability of this solution.
Will this hold up under heavy load?
cards.note: 'Scalability' is the property of a system to handle a growing amount of work by adding resources. It's a critical concern for long-term application health.

sideB: I'll send out a follow-up email with the meeting minutes.
Expect a recap email with the key takeaways shortly.
I will summarize our discussion and action items in an email.
cards.note: 'Meeting minutes' are a written record of a meeting. A follow-up email ensures everyone is aligned on decisions and action items.

sideB: Let's take this as an action item.
I'll add this to our list of action items.
This is a clear takeaway for us to work on.
cards.note: An 'action item' is a discrete task that arises from a meeting. Assigning them ensures accountability.

sideB: This is out of scope for the current sprint.
That falls outside the scope of this sprint's work.
We should probably tackle that in a future sprint.
cards.note: In Agile/Scrum, a 'sprint' has a defined scope of work. This phrase protects the team from unplanned work.

sideB: Let's add this to the backlog.
This sounds like a good candidate for the product backlog.
We can create a story for this in the backlog.
cards.note: The 'product backlog' is a prioritized list of all desired features and fixes for a product. It's a key component of Agile development.

sideB: I'm playing devil's advocate here.
To play devil's advocate for a moment...
Let me be the devil's advocate and challenge that assumption.
cards.note: Playing 'devil's advocate' means expressing an opposing view, not because you disagree, but to test the strength of an argument.

sideB: What are the dependencies for this task?
Is this task dependent on any other work?
What needs to be completed before we can start on this?
cards.note: In project management, a 'dependency' is a task that relies on the completion of another task.

sideB: This looks good to me, LGTM.
I've reviewed it, looks good to me.
LGTM, go ahead and merge it.
cards.note: 'LGTM' is a very common acronym in code reviews, meaning 'Looks Good To Me'. It's an informal way to approve changes.

sideB: Let's drill down into the performance metrics.
Can we take a deeper dive into the data?
Let's investigate the specifics of these numbers.
cards.note: 'Drill down' is a business intelligence term for exploring data at a more detailed level.

sideB: What's the root cause of this issue?
Have we identified the root cause yet?
We need to perform a root cause analysis (RCA).
cards.note: A 'root cause' is the fundamental reason for a problem. Fixing it prevents the problem from recurring, as opposed to just fixing the symptoms.

sideB: We need to get stakeholder buy-in on this.
Has this been approved by the stakeholders?
Let's secure stakeholder agreement before proceeding.
cards.note: A 'stakeholder' is anyone with an interest in the project. 'Buy-in' means getting their agreement and support.

sideB: This is a P1 (Priority 1) issue.
Let's classify this bug as a P1.
Given the impact, this is definitely a high-priority bug.
cards.note: 'P1' or 'P0' typically denotes the highest priority for a bug or task, meaning it must be addressed immediately.

sideB: Who is the DRI for this initiative?
We need to assign a Directly Responsible Individual.
Who's the DRI on this?
cards.note: 'DRI' stands for 'Directly Responsible Individual'. It's a management concept to ensure that a single person is accountable for a task or decision.

sideB: Just to piggyback on that idea...
If I can piggyback on what you just said...
To build on that point...
cards.note: 'Piggybacking' in a conversation means to use someone else's recently stated idea as a basis for your own point.

sideB: Can we get a quick sanity check on this?
I'd like someone to sanity-check my logic here.
Before we commit, let's do a sanity check.
cards.note: A 'sanity check' is a quick, high-level review to see if a proposed solution or result seems plausible and rational.

sideB: We're trying to boil the ocean here.
I think we're boiling the ocean with this approach.
Let's not boil the ocean; let's focus on a smaller part first.
cards.note: The idiom 'to boil the ocean' means to attempt an impossibly large task. It's used to suggest simplifying or narrowing the scope.

sideB: Let's not reinvent the wheel.
We should use an existing library instead of reinventing the wheel.
There's no need to reinvent the wheel for this.
cards.note: 'Reinventing the wheel' means wasting time creating something that has already been created and is readily available.

sideB: What are the next steps?
So, what are our next steps on this?
Let's define the next actionable steps.
cards.note: A crucial question to ask at the end of a discussion to ensure progress and clarity on what happens after the meeting.

sideB: I'm not following. Can you rephrase that?
I'm a bit lost, could you explain that differently?
Sorry, you lost me there. Can you repeat that?
cards.note: A polite and direct way to admit you don't understand something, which is much better than staying silent.

sideB: Are we all on the same page?
I want to make sure we're on the same page.
Let's just confirm everyone is aligned.
cards.note: This idiom means 'Do we all have a shared understanding of the situation?' It's used to check for consensus.

sideB: This will have a downstream impact.
We need to consider the downstream effects of this change.
The downstream impact on other teams could be significant.
cards.note: In a process or system, 'downstream' refers to the later stages or components that are affected by an earlier action.

sideB: Let's timebox this discussion to 10 minutes.
We'll timebox this to avoid going over.
Okay, we have a 10-minute timebox for this topic.
cards.note: 'Timeboxing' is a time management technique where a fixed maximum time is allocated to an activity. It's very common in Agile meetings.

sideB: That's a good point, I hadn't considered that.
You raise a valid point.
That's an interesting perspective.
cards.note: A phrase used to acknowledge and validate another person's contribution to the discussion, fostering a positive environment.

sideB: We'll have to agree to disagree.
It seems we won't reach a consensus, so let's agree to disagree.
Let's just agree to disagree on this and move on.
cards.note: A diplomatic way to end a debate where no agreement can be reached, allowing the meeting to continue.

sideB: What's the happy path for this user flow?
Let's first define the happy path scenario.
Does this cover the happy path?
cards.note: The 'happy path' is the default scenario featuring no exceptions or error conditions. It's the ideal, expected flow of a process.

sideB: We need to consider the edge cases.
What are the edge cases for this feature?
Have we handled all the edge cases?
cards.note: An 'edge case' is a problem or situation that occurs only at an extreme (maximum or minimum) operating parameter. It's the opposite of the 'happy path'.

sideB: My two cents on this is...
If I can add my two cents...
Here's my two cents, for what it's worth.
cards.note: The idiom 'my two cents' is a humble way of offering your opinion or perspective on a matter.

sideB: Let's try to dogfood this ourselves first.
We should dogfood this feature before releasing it.
The team will start dogfooding the new build tomorrow.
cards.note: 'Dogfooding' (from 'eating your own dog food') is the practice of a company using its own products to test and promote them.

sideB: This is a non-trivial amount of work.
The effort required for this is non-trivial.
Be aware that this is a non-trivial change.
cards.note: 'Non-trivial' is a common developer understatement. It means the task is actually quite complex and will require significant effort.

sideB: The latency is noticeable on the client-side.
We need to optimize the client-side rendering.
This operation is too heavy for the client-side.
cards.note: 'Client-side' refers to operations that are performed by the user's browser or device, as opposed to the 'server-side'.

sideB: Can we get a ballpark figure for the effort?
I don't need an exact number, just a ballpark estimate.
What's the ballpark on the timeline for this?
cards.note: A 'ballpark figure' or 'ballpark estimate' is a very rough, approximate numerical estimate.

sideB: Let's wrap up and summarize the action items.
To wrap up the meeting...
Okay, let's wrap this up.
cards.note: 'To wrap up' means to finish or conclude something. It's a standard phrase to signal the end of a meeting.
